title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
How does internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aid Spanish attempts to create their empire?

Small pox took out a lot of Native Americans during this time which weakened their empires drastically. The Incan empire was invaded with this disease which made it easier for Francisco Pizzaro to come in and seize the capital city. “But like the Aztecs, unrest between the Incas and conquered groups created tensions and left the empire vulnerable to foreigners. Smallpox spread in advance of Spanish conquerors and hit the Incan empire in 1525. Epidemics ravaged the population, cutting the empire’s population in half, killing the Incan emperor Huayna Capac and many members of his family and sparking a bloody war of succession.” With all of that happening, Francisco Pizzaro was able to deceive the Inca rulers and take control.
What racial system is established by the Spanish in the New World? Why is it established and how does it operate?

A racial hierarchy was marked in the New World in the mid-1600’s called Sistema de Castas. This system organized individuals into a variety of racial groups based on their “purity of blood.” It became almost prerequisites for social and political advancement in Spanish colonial society. Iberian-born Spaniards were at the highest level of administration and had the greatest estates. Below them are their descendants, which are New World-born Spaniards. Following them are the Mestizos, who were mixed Spanish and Indian heritage.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**How does internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aid Spanish attempts to create their empire?**
Native American empires such as the Aztecs consisted of fragile alliances of city states that wanted to break from their rule.  This aided the Spanish by allowing them to enlist these native allies to fight and overthrow the empires.

**What racial system is established by the Spanish in the New World?**
The Spanish established a racial system called the Sistema de Castas.  Rooted in medieval practices, this classified people into various racial groups based upon their supposed “purity of blood.” 

**Why is it established and how does it operate?**
It was established to rank people social and political advancement in Spanish colonial society.  It provided an excuse to empower Spaniards by their definition of superiority.
The blood line ranking was dominated first by the Iberian-born Spaniards known as the Peninulares or Espanoles. These individuals held the highest administration positions and estates.  The descendants, called Criollos, were next in line for opportunities.  Then the mixed Spanish and Indians were considered the lowest on the scale.

text:
**How does internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aid Spanish attempts to create their empire?**
Internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aided Spanish attempts to create their empire because it made them vulnerable. This was so because they didn't have a strong, united standing with one another, making it possible for Europeans to gain allies, take over smaller towns, and eventually the remainder of the Central and Southern Americas. 

**What racial system is established by the Spanish in the New World? Why is it established and how does it operate?**
The racial system established by the Spanish in the New World was formed so that Spaniards born in Spain were at the top social status, followed by Spaniards born in New Spain, then those of Spanish and Native American descent, and last Native Americans and slaves. The Spanish believed the more "pure" your blood, the higher your status. This was established to form a social structure and provide a "prerequisite for social and political advancement", as mentioned in the text.

- The Spanish wanted to take over the natives land because of the wealth and happiness it could bring to them. Central and South America was rumored to have fortunes around the land.

2. In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants, and animals were exchanged? The diseases that Europeans brought over to the Americas were measles, smallpox and influenza. Domesticated animals, squash, beans, corn and tobacco were among the many things traded between the Native Americans and the Europeans.

3. What are the ways that European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?
- The pope authorized the Europeans to claim the land, claimed they discovered the land, and claiming they improved the land from the people they took it over from.

**How does internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aid Spanish attempts to create their empire?**
With the tension it was easy for Spain to gain allies within the Americas to topple the larger civilizations. Especially when the Aztecs even considered Cortez to be the God Quetzacoatl. **What racial system is established by the Spain in the new world? Why is it established and how does it operate?**
1. Espanoles: Natural born Spaniards occupied the highest level of administration.
2. Criolles: New-World born Spaniards they rivaled the Espanoles for wealth and opportunity.
3. Mestizos: Mixed Spanish and Indian were like the middle class.
4.Slaves/Indians: Lowest Rung
The Spaniards were outnumbered so they needed a way to incorporate Native Americans into colonial life even if it was terribly unequal. If you were "pure-blood" you had land and wealth in the colony. Half bloods and even Spaniards born in the New World were given much less than the pure bloods. They were middle class of the society, they did all of the work for little reward. Slaves and Indians had the very bottom rung of the society. They were eventually freed of the colonies so called slavery laws only to be forced into equally grueling work in a system of land-based forced labor.

text:
**What were the goals of the Spanish (individually and as a nation) in establishing an empire in the Americas?**
In religious regards, the goal of the Spanish was to win the land and people for the Catholic church, as mentioned in the lecture. In regards to power and expansion, the goal was to gain power over the Americas (central and southern) and to seek out the fortunes that were rumored to be there. 

**In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants, and animals were exchanged?**
The diseases exchanged from Europeans to Native Americans included smallpox, influenza, and measles. Plants and animals exchanged between Europeans and Native Americans include: large, domesticated animals; corns, beans, squash, and potatoes; and tobacco plants. 

**What are the ways that European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?
**
The ways that Europeans claim their right to claim land in the Americas include: authority extended by the pope; claims of discovery of the land; claiming they commandeered the land from the previous people; occupying the land; and improving the land.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**What were the goals of the Spanish in establishing a nation in the Americas?**

 The majority of the goals set by the Spanish were power and glory drive.  They wanted to win the lands and the people for the catholic church and spread Catholicism across the Americas. They also wanted to seek out the rumored treasures including gold and gems, increase their power in world affairs, and bring North and South Americas under their control.

**In the biological exchange between the Europeans and Native Americans what diseases, plants, and animals were exchanged?**

The diseases brought to New World from Europe were influenza, measles and most devastating, small pox, which decreased the population from 1 million to 500 in a span of 50 years. In addition to diseases, Europe introduced large domestic animals such as cattle and sheep, onions, turnips, citrus and other fruits, the honey bee, and my personal favorite, the coffee bean.  From America, the Europeans brought back things such as various veggies including corn, beans, and others higher in nutrition compared to their local agriculture, tobacco, the cacao bean, vanilla, turkeys, and various squashes.

**What are the ways that European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?**

The Europeans claimed the land by the authority extended by the pope, claiming they discovered the land, and claiming that they had conquered the people of the land.  They also occupied and improved the  land.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**What were the goals of the Spanish (individually and as a nation) in establishing an empire in the Americas?**
The religious goals of Spain were to win land and peoples for the catholic church. It's secular aims were to bring central and south america under their control, increase the power of spain in world affairs, and seek out great wealth for rumored gold and gems in the Americas.
Their individual ambitions were fueled by power and glory. Since Spain was a stratified society, the Americas offered tempting opportunities for social and political advancement

**In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants and animals were exchanged?**
Unfortunately the Europeans introduced a number of diseases that wiped out an enormous amount of Native Americans.  These included small pox, influenza, measles, typhus, Malaria, Diphtheria, and whooping cough.
Aside from diseases, the Europeans also brought large domestic mammals to the Americas such as cattle, sheep, pigs, and horses. Honeybees, wheat and rye were also part of their exchange.
The Americas offered many foods such as coffee, peaches, pears, olive, citrus fruit, bananas, sugar cane, onions, grains, turnips, grapes, corn, beans, squash, and potatoes. Tobacco was also a huge export that became significant plant in the British colonies.

**What’s Sovereignty?**
The claiming of right and control over regions. 

**What are the ways that European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?**
They claimed their right by the authority extended by the pope. Other ways included the right of possession by discovery, by conquering the people, by occupying the land, and by improving the land.

- The Spanish’s religious goals were to win the lands and peoples for the catholic church. Their secular goals included bringing central and south America under their control to increase the power of Spain and world affairs, to seek out great wealth, and to gratify their individual ambitions for power and glory.

2) In the biological exchange between European and Native Americans, what diseases, plants and animals were exchanged?

- Diseases carried from the old world to the new world killed millions of Native Americans who had no immunity to germs that had infested Europe, Asia, and Africa for centuries.The worst disease was smallpox which spread from direct human contact. Other diseases that affected the Native American’s were influenza and measles. Europeans introduced large, domesticated mammals to the America’s. They exchanged corn, bean, squash, potatoes, tobacco plant, and horses.

3) What are the ways that European powers claim their rights to claim land in the America?

- The Europeans claimed their power over the land with authority extended by the Pope. They claimed their right of possession by claiming they discovered the land, conquered the people of the land, occupying the land, and improving the land.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**What were the goals of the spanish (individually and as a nation) in establishing an empire in the Americas?** Religiously, the Spanish wanted establish themselves in the Americas to further popularize the Catholic Church. From a non-religious perspective, their goal was to control Central and South America, in order to increase the power of their empire. They also sought wealth in the form of gold. Lastly, Spain believed that the Americas brought great opportunity for social and political advancement.

**In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants and animals were exchanged?** The disease that were brought over included smallpox, influenza, and measles. These diseases brought great havoc to the native lands because they lacked the immunities that the Europeans had. In regards to animals, the Europeans brought over large livestock, such as cattle, sheep, and pigs. The European people also gained more nutritious vegetables such as beans, squash and corn from their time in the Americas. The Europeans also discovered tobacco, which quickly became popular throughout Europe. In contrast, the Native Americans gained the use of horses, which forever changed their method of travel.

**What are the ways that European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?** One example would be that they would use the authority of the pope. Another being that they were the ones to originally discover the land. They also claimed that they conquered the people of the land. The Europeans also claimed possession by occupying the land. Lastly, they claimed possession by improving the land.

text:
**Week One: The New World**
 
**Comment [1]**

**When does American History Begin?**

Before 1492 and Columbus it suggests how deeply rooted our false notions of Native peoples were. It views them as unchanging and a primitive society. The idea that Native American societies changed only a little until Europeans arrived has only been seriously countered over the last few decades. 

**What was the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies? What role does giving play in establishing status and obligation?**

Exchanges included, material good, marriage, resources, labor, ideas, techniques, religiousness practices
Exchanges sealed political and social relationships. Rather than accumulate materials wealth most would give it away to earn prestige and respect, this placed obligations on others to reciprocate 

**What developments occur in Europe that helped set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?**

All of European nations started to experience massive growth and population after the 15th century plague.
Population growth brought the growth of national economies and rising demands for consumer goods.
Growing demand lead to the development of advances of ships building and navigation so that sea merchants could compete more effectively in expanding trade.
The resurgence of trade also lead to the rise of large kingdoms and powerful monarchs who wanted to consolidate their power and increase their economic development of their nations.
Only powerful kingdoms could pull together the resources that were necessary to support large scaled voyages of exploration and trade. 
European nations were fascinated and hungry for increase trade with the wealthy nations of Asia. 

**What was Portugal’s interest in slaves? Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?**

Slaves were not just an after thought in attempt to gain a place in the gold trade. There was an increase need for slave labor in the sugar plantation growth. The Portuguese traded with the Moors who were long established slaves suppliers. As the Portuguese traveled towards the Senegal River they discover that there were other Africans who engage in the slave trade. In the 1500 the Portuguese had turned themselves into a major slave purchaser and seller in West Africa.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**Comment [2]**

**What were the three major crops developed in the Americas? What impact did they have?**

There were three major crops; corn, beans, and squash, the so- called “three sisters” that provided nutritional needs necessary to sustain cities and civilizations. 

**What were the major differences between Native American and European people?**

Europeans had established communities where they lived and worked. Native Americans had settlements, but they were nomadic, following the game that sustained them. 
Europeans were predominantly Christian, but Native Americans were more Deists, believing in the existence and powers of many spirits. 
The music of Europeans was complex, using percussion, wind, and stringed instruments where Native Americans expressed music principally with drums. 
Europeans obtained their food principally from farming and animal husbandry. While some Native Americans planted crops, many were "hunter-gatherers". 
Europeans passed information along through writing. Native Americans passed information verbally and had no written language. They did use symbols for spirits that they held as being important.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**Comment [3]**

**What roles do sugar and slavery play in the expansion of European empires?**

Sugar was a wildly profitable commodity and it had become popular luxury among the nobility wealthy of Europe. The Portuguese began growing sugar cane along the Mediterranean, but it was a difficult crop due to the growing conditions. The Portuguese found new land in the Atlantic Islands and Portugal’s would-be planters needed laborers to cultivate the difficult, labor-intensive crop. Portuguese merchants would trade guns, iron and manufactured goods for slaves who were owned by powerful African kingdoms, Slaves would work the sugar fields and began the first great Atlantic plantations. 

**What diseases devastate Native American peoples?**

Native Americans lacked the immunities that Europeans and Africans had developed over centuries of deadly epidemics and so when Europeans arrived, carrying smallpox, typhus, influenza, diphtheria, measles, and hepatitis, plagues decimated native communities.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
1) Their goals were both religious and secular. Regarding the former, their goal was to win over the land and its inhabitants for the Roman Catholic Church. Regarding the latter, it was to bring the land under Spanish control, increase Spanish power in world affairs, to acquire the great wealth rumored to be in the Americas, and finally on the individual level to advance politically and socially.

2) The Spanish brought with them diseases from the Old World that people in the New World did not have immunity to. Greatest among these was smallpox, but also influenza and measles. Europeans introduced large domesticated mammals such as horses to the Americas and brought back with them new vegetables like corn, beans squash, and potatoes. Horses began to play a prominent role in the Great Planes with the Natives who resided there while tobacco from the Americas became a phenomenon in Europe and particularly Britain.

3) Europeans claimed possession and authority over huge swaths of land from the Pope, the idea that they "discovered" the land in question, that they conquered the people in the land, occupying the land, and finally the notion that they were somehow "improving" the land, which I find odd given that so many Natives died due to their arrival.

text:
**What were the three major crops developed in the Americas? What impact did they have?**

	The three major crops that were developed in the Americas were corn, beans and squash, also known as the “three sisters.” These crops provided the all the nutrients needed in order to sustain the people of the cities and civilizations. 

**What were the major differences between Native American and European peoples?**

	The major differences between Native American and European people were their beliefs on property rights, kinship networks and spiritual practices

Property rights – the Native Americans felt as if they were the rightful owners of items, land and crops because they actively used them. But simply using the land did not mean they had the right to possess it permanently. 
Kinship networks – Most Native Americans lived in small communities and families were identified through the females, the mothers and daughters. 
Spiritual practices – There was no differentiation between the natural and supernatural for the Native Americans.

text:
**1.**  Sugar was a luxury among the wealthy and powerful European classes.  It was once an exotic commodity from Asia that eventually was harvested in the Atlantic Islands.  Since sugar is a difficult crop, the Portuguese needed laborers to cultivate the plant.  This led to the slavery of the islands natives known as the Guanches and eventually to the slave trade of African kingdoms in exchange for guns, iron and other goods.
All of this was the start of the great Atlantic plantations, controlled by the European empires.

**2.** Native Americans lacked the immunities to the  deadly epidemics of smallpox, typhus, influenza, diphtheria, measles, and hepatitis.  These developed into plagues that decimated native communities.  Some scholars estimated that within the first century and a half of European contact, as much as 90 percent of the population of the Americas perished.

The peoples of the Algonkian and Ojibwe developed written languages, skilled weavers produced clothing and textiles, metalworkers produced practical tools like fishhooks or weapons, and artists made decorative jewelry.

**2.** The major differences could be found in farming techniques, social traits and property rights.
Native American farmers engaged in permanent, intensive agriculture, using hand tools rather than European-style plows.  They also shared some broad traits in Spiritual practices, beliefs on property, and kinship networks.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

selector.exact: Native cultures understood ancestry as matrilineal: family and clan identity proceeded along the female line, through mothers and daughters, rather than fathers and sons. Fathers, for instance, would often join mothers’ extended families and sometimes even a mother’s brothers would take a more direct role in child-raising than biological fathers. Mothers could therefore often wield enormous influence at local levels and native mens’ identities and influence were often forged in such matrilineal contexts. Native American culture meanwhile generally afforded greater sexual and marital freedom. Women often chose their husbands, and divorce often was a relatively simple and straightforward process.

-They wanted to win the lands and people for the Catholic Church. They wanted to bring central and South America under their control and to increase Spain's power in world affairs. They also wanted to gain wealth from the gold and gems in America.

2)In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants and animals were exchanged?

-Diseases were brought into the New World and killed many natives because they had no immunity to those diseases. Some examples of diseases brought in were smallpox, influenza, and measles. text:
When does American History begin?

American History began before Christopher Columbus sailed in 1492. The Native Americans existed before the arrival of the Europeans and are believed to have migrated from Asia about 20,000 years ago.


What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligations?

Exchanges included food, marriages, labor, religious practices, languages, cultures, ideas and techniques.  Political relationships were created as a result of these exchanges. Exchanges also sealed social relationships and those with more wealth gave some away to gain prestige and were thought of highly by others. In return, the giving placed an obligation to others to give back or give some other favor. Giving was a sign of a standing respect.

What developments occur in Europe that set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?

Europe recovered from a deadly epidemic that wiped out nearly half of the population. What followed was a growing economy and a high demand for consumer goods. This demand led to advances to the development of ship building and navigation for trade expansion. In addition, the rising powerful monarchies wanted to consolidate power and increase their economic development of the countries. The European nations always pursued better ways to trade.

What was Portugal’s interest in salves? What role does the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves? 

They acquired slaves to work on their growing sugar plantations.  They traded with other people on slaves, as well as became middlemen of slave trade and expanded it across the world.

text:
When does American History begin?

Native American history goes back approximately twelve to twenty thousand years ago where it’s believed that the first inhabitants may have come from Asia. From the time approximately after the last Ice Age, societies sprung up and thrived until Europeans came to their lands in 1492. That’s when Native American and American history collides and for the most part is referred to as American history from that point on.

What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies?

There were many varied forms of exchanges that occured in the confines of the Native American societies and groups. Material goods were often exchanged in order to help the other communities as well as labor, ideas and techniques. The further the distance of the exchanges, the more varied the differences would be between the groups conducting the exchange. This could mean more distinct differences in languages and cultures, but it didn’t prevent these alliances from happening.

What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?

Much the way giving does now, when you give to a neighbor or neighboring community, those parties will feel obligated to help or give back to you or your community in some way. The more a person or community gave, the more respect gained in not only their community, but outside of their particular area as well.

What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?

Europe had the benefit of a booming population and economy while on the mend from The Plague that decimated a lot of their country. With more people, more supplies and resources were needed. Resources were then needed from all areas, not just from Europe and this led to more shipbuilding and navigation technologies which would help supply all the needed resources from across the seas. The hierarchy in place was able to maintain this type of trading system while also trying to expand trade more and more and also upgrade their status as a trade country. This allowed Europe and European areas to open trades with Asian markets as they became known as wealthy partners.

What was Portugal’s interest in slaves?

The slave trade was useful to Portugal as they had large sugar plantations that needed harvesting. Without enough of their own workers to properly and quickly do this, they relied on the slave labor force to ensure that this was could be done to keep up with their crop demands.


What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?

As Portugal became more and more heavily invested in the slave trade, other countries also noticed the rewards that this brought. Portugal became a “middle-man” of sorts and this allowed slavery to expand quickly beyond Portugal’s sugar crops

text:
**When does American History begin?**
* American History began before Columbus arrived in 1492. 

**What were the variety of exchange that occurred in Native American societies?**
* Material goods, resources, labor, marriages, religion, cultures, ideas, and techniques.

**What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?**
* Giving was seen as a way of respect for the Native Americans. Those who gave were thought highly of, and also allowed others to feel obligated to return the favor or express their gratitude for their generosity in some other way.

**What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?**
* European population recovers from the plague in the 14th century that wiped out half of the region.
* Population growth led to growth of national economies, which led to the rise in demand of goods
* The demand of goods resulted in expanding trade through shipping, building and navigating.
* The expansion of trade led to the rise of Kingdoms and powerful monarchs and allowed them to join their powers to increase economic development in their nations.
* These powerful nations were able to gather their wealth and resources to support large voyages of exploration and trade
* European nations looked for better routes of trade and exploration with wealthy nations of asia.

**What was Portugal’s interest in slaves? **
* Sugar plantations spread westward, leading to an increase in need for slave labor. 

**What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of American slaves?**

* The Portugese became the middle men in the slave trade, buying and selling slaves.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
**When does American History begin?**
American history began far before Columbus’ landing in 1492.  Native Americans existed and thrived in changing and developing societies, before the arrival of the Europeans.  American history most likely began with the migration of the first people from Asia between twelve and twenty thousand years ago.

**What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies?**
Exchanges occurred with material goods, represented in marriages across community lines, resources, labor, ideas, techniques, and religious practices. Longer distances frequently crossed exchanges of cultural and language boundaries.  From casual to widespread alliances that were economical, political, and religious.

**What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?**
Giving placed an obligation to others to reciprocate for favors.  The more you gave gained you standing and respect by having others owe you.

**What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?**
* First all european nations began to experience massive growth of population, recovering from an epidemic of plague from the 14th century that killed 1/2 the population of the region. 
* Second, the population growth brought the growth of national economies, and rising demand of consumer goods. 
* Third, this growing demand brought the development of advances in ship building and navigation so sea merchants could compete more effectively in expanding trade. 
* Fourth, the resurgence of trade also led to the rise of large kingdoms and powerful monarchs. They consolidated their power and increased the economic power of their nations. 
* Fifth, only these powerful nations could pool together their wealth and  resources that was necessary to support large scale voyages of exploration and trade. 
* Finally, these European nations sought better and more effective routes of trade and exploration with wealthy nations of Asia.

**What was Portugal’s interest in slaves?**
Slavery survived since the time of the Romans, especially in the growing of sugar. As sugar plantations spread westward, there was an increasing need for slave labor. The Portuguese traded with the Moors and discovered that as they traveled towards the Senegal river, other African peoples engaged in this slave trade with the Moors of North Africa.

**What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?**
Wanting to initially control the gold trade and find a passage to the East, they essentially became middle men in the slave trade.  At the beginning of the 1500’s the Portuguese had turn themselves into both major purchasers and sellers of slaves in West Africa.  By entering into this trade, they transformed the slave trade and practice of slavery across the world.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
1.) When does American history begin?
True American history begins pre Christopher Columbus’s arrival on an island off the coast of the Bahamas in 1492, and in actuality begins with the core migration and settlement of native’s across the North American landscape as early as the first century. However, their more complex adaptation of the landscape and true societal origins begin to form around the 11th century.  

2.) What was the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American societies? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?

The variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American societies was a direct result of the wide variety of social and cultural interactions that took place within the native people both in minute and grand scale; ranging from person to person or society to society. The exchanges themselves ranged from material goods to natural resources and labor, but also included marriage and the existential transference of ideas, techniques and religious practices. While the exchanges themselves took place in the form of causal encounters and widespread networks, they manifested across the spectrums of economic, political and religious impact; resulting in a broader absorption of the greater people because of the role giving played amongst these societies. Often, acquired wealth was given away in an effort to earn more prestige amongst your peers, in turn flipping the perception of financial prosperity from palpable wealth to generalized respect. This respect not only would establish an immense amount of status for an individual but would also allow that person to accumulate an immense amount of obligation as well, because as the wealth was given away the obligation was then placed on others to reciprocate the generous deed through favors instead of finance. This form of financial generosity led to this in-debt system, where people would owe favors instead of finances and assets, and status could be perceived by that persons withstanding in the community in terms of how many people ‘obliged’ to them. 

3.) What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?

With the onset of the 15th century, several developments occurred in Europe that set the stage for the foundation of European empire building and their interest in expanding exploration. First off, Europe as a whole experienced an inordinate amount of population stimulation and growth after the detrimental effect the Black plague of the 14th century had on the overall census. This uncanny population growth, however anticipated due to evolutionary generalized growth, led to an immense amount of fiscal growth amongst the greater European nations, and as the economies became more and more stimulated the demand for resources and consumer goods increased. These nations, to combat this growing demand, redirected their efforts and began investing their time and resources to furthering the development of shipbuilding and navigation to enable and improve sea merchants to compete within the ever-expanding trade networks across the globe. This resurgence of trade led to the growth of powerful kingdoms and powerful monarchs who had the ulterior motives of consolidating their powers and increasing their economic growth, for example: King Henry VII and the Tudor Dynasty in England and Ferdinand and Isabella’s reign in Spain. Only the powerful nations could pool together enough resources to fund large scale explorations in trade, and their undying fascination and hunger for increased trade with the immensely wealthy country of Asia began to drive the need for more effective routes of trade and transportation. This indirectly led to these countries building empires as the expanded their nation’s power across the globe as they sought the east, unintentionally opening up the unknown riches the rest of the world could provide to them. 

4.) What was Portugal’s interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves? 

Essentially Portugal’s motives indirectly began with the existence of slaves in Southern Europe in the mid 14th century where labor was scarce and the need for this forced later was extremely prevalent. With what began in the Roman Empire, sugar growing expanded into a popular form of agriculture amongst Europe as sugar plantations spread throughout the nation; from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic, increasing the need for slave labor for a small country such as Portugal specifically. Originally, prince Henry the Navigator, son of King John the first, (of portugal) led expeditions to the west coast of Africa to control the gold trade and hopefully find new routes to the east. As the need for slave labor increased in the European nations, Portugal’s already engrained roots in the West African slave trade would allow them to initiate the Atlantic trade of African slaves, becoming a major player in the buying and selling of slaves, evolving into the middle men of this human commerce. Ultimately, Portugal’s integral role in the slave trade transformed the industry itself, but also carried the ramifications of revolutionizing the practice itself through the world expansions of the European powers.

text:
**When does American History Begin?**
American history began before Columbus' "discovery" in 1492, when Native Americans migrated to America.

**What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?** Exchanges were made on a personal and more widespread level. Exchange does not just refer to physical materials, but also labor, ideas, and resources. Exchange was a heavy part of establishing personal and and community wide relationships, as it was capable of breaking language barriers and cultural differences, making a powerful form of communication. Those that accumulated wealth gave away much of their goods in order to gain the favor of their community. It also was used to create a sense of obligation to the recipients of the gift, so that they can later repay the favor.

**What developments occur in Europe that set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?** Europe had just been recovering from the catastrophic plague that wiped out nearly half of their population, so they were in a time of expansion. This includes a growing population, which led to a growing national economy. The growing economy led to improvements in naval technology, which expanded trade within and outside Europe. Trade gave Europe the ability to develop monarchs and kings. These newly created Kingdoms were now healthy enough to explore foreign lands.

**What was Portugal's interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?** Portugal had an expanding future in sugar crops, but lacked the labor to harvest them. The Portuguese initially traded slaves with the Moors, but soon found themselves trading with anyone. Portugal's involvement with slavery made it more common on a global level.

text:
**When does American history begin?
**
American history began when native people first migrated to the America's (north and south) across the Bering Strait from Asia. 

**What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American societies? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?**
The variety of exchanges include: trading of material goods, exchanges represented in marriage, exchange of resources for labor, and exchange of ideas, techniques, and religious practices. Giving played a role in establishing status by earning an individual prestige by proving wealth. Giving played a role in establishing obligation by making the receiver of gifts feel that they owe the giver something in return. 

**What developments occur in Europe that set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?**
Developments that occurred in Europe that set the foundation for European exploration and empire building consist of: Europe experiencing massive growth in population, growth of national economies and consumer demand, advancements in technology, a rise in kingdoms with powerful monarchs with adequate resources, and search of better means of travel. 

**What was Portugal's interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?**
Portugal's interest in slaves was initially due to the increased need for labor in the ever expanding sugar crops. Portugal's role in the African slave trade became that of the middleman.

text:
What consists Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs? 
There is five stage model. First level is the "Physiological Needs" An individual person must have food, air, water, sleep in order to go to the second level which is the "Safety Needs". People needs to be comfortable in order for him/her to feel safe. On the third level, a person must met "Social Needs". That's why a person cannot just live with his or herself because the need of love and family is essential. Everyone needs to feel an affection whether it is by friends or by family. The fourth level is "Esteem Needs", every person needs to feel respected because a positive feeling is a must with every person. Lastly, when a person met all the 4 levels of maslow's, there is "Self Actualization Needs" which is "realizing full potential". This one is important because this is where a person realizes all the experiences and learn by it. By satisfying all of these, an individual is considered complete and whole as a person.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
How does internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aid Spanish attempts to create their empire?
Small pox took out a lot of Native Americans during this time which weakened their empires drastically. The Incan empire was invaded with this disease which made it easier for Francisco Pizzaro to come in and seize the capital city. “But like the Aztecs, unrest between the Incas and conquered groups created tensions and left the empire vulnerable to foreigners. Smallpox spread in advance of Spanish conquerors and hit the Incan empire in 1525. Epidemics ravaged the population, cutting the empire’s population in half, killing the Incan emperor Huayna Capac and many members of his family and sparking a bloody war of succession.” With all of that happening, Francisco Pizzaro was able to deceive the Inca rulers and take control.
What racial system is established by the Spanish in the New World? Why is it established and how does it operate?
A racial hierarchy was marked in the New World in the mid-1600’s called Sistema de Castas. This system organized individuals into a variety of racial groups based on their “purity of blood.” It became almost prerequisites for social and political advancement in Spanish colonial society. Iberian-born Spaniards were at the highest level of administration and had the greatest estates. Below them are their descendants, which are New World-born Spaniards. Following them are the Mestizos, who were mixed Spanish and Indian heritage.

text:

As a nation, Spain aimed not only to control Central and South America, but to use that control to convert natives to the catholic church.  Spain wanted greater influence in the world.  Individually, Spain established an empire in the Americas for wealth and to advance socially and politically.

2.  In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants and animals were exchanged?  Small pox, influenza, and measles arrived along with the Europeans to the New World and ravaged communities that had no immunity for these diseases.  Potatoes, tomatoes, corn, vanilla, tobacco, and turkey are some notable plants and animals that were exchanged from the New World to Europe.  Sugar cane, coffee, sheeps, pigs, and horses are notable plants and animals that were exchanged from Europe to the New World.

3.  What were the ways European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?  Europeans claimed their right to land by the authority of the pope, by claiming they "discovered" the land, claiming to have conquered the people of the land, and also claimed that they were improving the land.

text:
What  were the goals of the Spanish (individually and as a nation) establishing an empire in the Americas?

The Spanish came to the America's central south, the Caribbean, and eventually the north with dreams of building an empire both secular and religious. The Spanish quickly adapted  to the role of  authoritarian over the Americas. Their religious  goals were simple, to win all lands and the peoples for the Catholic religion. Their  secular aim included bringing central and south America under their control, and increasing  the power of Span in world  affairs. The Spanish came in search of great wealth, both in gold and gems that were rumored to be throughout America. This gratified their individual ambition for power and glory. Span was an especially stratified society and the Americas offered socially and political advancement.

In the biological  exchange between European and Native Americans, what diseases, plants and animals were exchanged?

The transfer of European diseases such as smallpox, influenza and measles had catastrophic repercussions which devastated the Native American population, other contributions  to the exchange were corn, bean, squash, potatoes and tobacco plants and  horses. 

What are the ways that European powers claim their rights to claim land in the America?

The Europeans ides of land ownership was established by a relentless legal system and the Pope, who believe their God commanded the land. These claims were orchestrated through force and conflict. The European took authority over the land with claims that they discovered, improved and where the rightful  owners.

In many cases, Europeans simply took the land that they wanted.  In other cases the Europeans co-existed on the land with the Natives only to make  future claims from outside settlers.

tags: QUESTIONS TO VIDEO WEEK 3-COLLISION OF CULTURES
text:
1.	**What were the goals of the Spanish? (Individually and as a nation) in establishing an empire in Americas? **
 Spain’s religious goals were simple: to win these lands and people for the Catholic Church.  The secular aims included bringing Central America and South America under their control to increase the power of Spain and world affairs, to seek wealth both gold and gems that were rumored to be everywhere in the Americas, to gratify their individual ambitions for power and glory.  Spain was an especially stratified society and the Americas offered tempting opportunities for social and political advancement.
 
**2.	In the biological exchange between Europeans and Native Americans, what diseases, plants, and animals were exchanged?**

The greatest killer (disease) was small pox which spread by direct human contact.  Other diseases that wreaked havoc on native communities included influenza (flu) and measles.  When Columbus landed on Hispaniola, the second largest island of the Antilles, lied east of Cuba, about 1 million people lived there.  Fifty years later, only 500 were still alive.  Even in the north where smaller Native American populations initially encountered only a few European explorers, traders, and fishermen.  Disease ravaged the countryside
     The exchange of disease was only a part of the boarder mutual transfer of plants and animals that resulted from European voyagers of explorations, settlement, and conquest.
     European introduced large domesticated mammals to the Americas.  They obtained from the new world a variety of vegetables, such as corn, beans, squash, and potatoes that were more nutritious than the old world wheat and rye.  The exchange of two other commodities significantly influenced two worlds.  In America, the Europeans discovered tobacco, a particularly significant plant in the establishment of the British colonies.  Tobacco for smoking and chewing quickly became a fad in Europe.
     Horses brought to the Americas by Europeans radically transformed Native American cultures and were traded north through Mexico into the Great Planes where a variety of planes nations peoples adapted their nomadic lifestyles to include the animal.

**3.	What is sovereignty?**
The dictionary defines sovereignty as supremacy of authority or rule as exercised in a territory existing as an independent political entity.

**4.	What are the ways that European powers claim their right to claim land in the Americas?**
They claimed they claimed the right of possessions of these huge regions of land by authority extended by a pope.  They claimed their right of possession by claiming they discovered the land. They claimed their right of possession by claiming to have conquered the people on that land.  They claimed their right of possession by occupying their land.  And finally, they made these claims of possession by improving the land.

unrest between the Incas and conquered groups created tensions it  left the empire vulnerable Smallpox spread out to the Incan empire. Also many of the region’s semi-independent city-states wanted to break from Aztec. 

**What racial system is established by the Spanish in the New World? Why is it established and how does it operate?**

The Sistema de Castas organized individuals into various racial groups based upon their supposed “purity of blood.” Various classifications—often elaborately arrived at—became almost prerequisites for social and political advancement in Spanish colonial society. 
Peninsulares—Iberian-born Spaniards, or Españoles–occupied the highest levels of administration and acquired the greatest estates. Their descendants, New World-born Spaniards, or criollos, occupied the next rung and rivaled the peninsulares for wealth and opportunity. Mestizos–a term used to describe those of mixed Spanish and Indian heritage–followed.

text:
Question 1: **What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American societies? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?**

- The variety of exchanges included not only goods, but marriages, resources, labor, ideas, techniques and religious practices. In doing this, the Natives had established a statuses of respect and prestige throughout their community. Once this act had been acquired, they would be obligated to return the same behavior.

Question 2: **What developments occur in Europe that help set foundation for European exploration and empire building?**

- All nations were beginning to experience a massive growth and population, rising economy (demand for consumer goods), ship building and navigation, the rise of large kingdoms and powerful monarchs. Powerful kingdoms could pull together the resources that were necessary to support large scale voyages of exploration and trade.

Question 3: **What was Portugal's interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African Slaves?**

- Slavery had survived since the time of the Romans. Portugal had become known for producing sugar crops and eventually had sugar plantations growing from the Mediterranean Sea to the Atlantic Islands, increasing their need for slaves. The Portuguese became the "middle man" in a trade of slaves in West Africa - expanding slavery across the world.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text:
What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation? The Native Americans exchanged material goods, marriages across community lines, resources, labor of ideas, techniques and religious practices. Exchanges sealed social and political relationships. It was done to earn prestige, where they would be thought highly of by the individual or group who had received the exchange, Also, by giving away things, it makes the other party obligated to give something back or do a favor. Exchanges also lead to respect in their eyes.

What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?

First, there was a massive growth in population recovering from the plague of the fourteenth century killing half the population of the region. Second, population growth brought the growth of national economies and raised the demand for consumer goods. Third, this growth led to the development of advances of shipbuilding and navigation so that sea merchants could compete more effectively in expanding trade. Fourth, these trades led to the rise of large kingdoms and powerful monarchs who wanted to consolidate their power and increase the economical development of their nation.

What was Portugal's interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?

Portugal’s interest in slaves was from the growth of sugar and sugar plantations that spread from the Mediterranean Sea to the Atlantic island off the coast of Africa. There was an increase in slave labor, and so the Portuguese traded with the Moors. By the beginning of the 1500's, the Portuguese had turned themselves into major purchasers and sellers of slaves in West Africa. They became the middle men in the trade in slaves in West Africa that had existed prior to their arrival.

text:
1) When does American history begin?
Native Americans had their own culture, beliefs, and economies. Their society changed very little until the Europeans arrived.
2) What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Societies?  What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation?
The Native Americans exchanged a variety of things ranging from marriages to material goods. A couple examples of what they exchanged are resource, labor, ideas, techniques, and religious practices. Those who earned material possessions often gave it away to acquire a higher status in its society. It also gave the person who received the gift an obligation to give something back.
3) What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?
After a massive plague, the European nations experienced a massive population growth in the 14th century. This brought growth in their Economies and rose the demand for consumer goods. This growing demand led to development of new technologies in ship building and navigation so that merchants can compete more effectively in expanding trade. The reestablishment of trade led to large kingdoms and thus increasing the economic development of those kingdoms. Also, because of the growth of these kingdoms, they can find all the resources necessary to support large scale exploration and trade. Finally, the European countries wanted to trade with the wealthy parts of Asia and therefore, with their new advancements, finding more effective ways to trade with them.
4) What was Portugal's interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves?
Portugal used slave trade to gain a place in the gold trade. Also, labor became more and more scarce due to the plague, slaves were used as labor for sugar planting.  As sugar planting became more and more widespread in Europe, ranging from West Mediterranean to the Atlantic Islands, the demand for slaves increased. Due to this demand, the Portugese soon became a middleman for the slave trade. By the 1500s, the Portugese became a major seller and purchaser of slaves. They transformed the slave trade and the practice of slavery, making it much more widespread.

text:
****What were the variety of exchanges that occurred In Native American Societies?  
****
Exchanges that are represented in marriages across community lines.  The exchange of resource and labor, ideas, techniques, and religious practices.  Longer distance exchanges frequently crossed cultural and language boundaries and ranged from casual encounters to widespread alliances and networks that were economic, political, and religious.  For both individual and religious communities, exchanges sealed social and political relationships rather than accumulate material wealth such as possessions.  Most who acquired this kind of wealth gave it away.  

    **What role did giving pay in establishing status and obligation? **

They did this to earn prestige, you were thought of more highly by individuals or groups you gave things to, and this was done to also place obligation on other to reciprocate, that is if I gave something to somebody, for example, they were kind of obligated to give me something back or to do a favor for me at another time.  For example, by giving things to other people, you gained understanding and respect in their eyes, and they kind of vote you.  You’re establishing their obligation to you.

**What developments occurred in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building?**

First all the European nations were beginning to experience a massive growth in population recovering from the terrible epidemic of the plague of the 14th century which killed nearly half the population of the region 
     Second, population growth brought the growth of national economies and rising demand for consumer goods.  
Third, this growing demand led to the development of the advancement of ship building and navigation so that sea merchants could compete more effectively in expanding trade.  
Fourth, the insurgents of trade also led to the rise of large kingdoms and powerful monarchs who wanted to consolidate their power and increase the economic development of their nations.  So, in England, for example, we see the rise of Henry the 7th, who establishes the Tudor, and he begins uniting land that had been divided for generations.  In France, there is the rise of Francis the 1st who established a claim of almost unchallenged authority.  In Spain, Ferdinand and Isabella, rulers of the independent state of Aragon and Costa, married and combined their kingdoms and then creating as we now know as Spain.
Fifth, only such powerful kingdoms could pull together the resources that was necessary to support large-scale voyagers of exploration and trade.  
Sixth, final ally these European nations, fascinated by and hungry for increased trade, with the wealthy nations of Asia, sought better and more effective routes of trade and transportation now  

**What was Portugal’s interest in slaves? **

 As sugar plantations spread westward, from the Mediterranean to the Atlantic islands of the coast of Africa, there was an increasing need for slave labor.  The Portuguese’s traded with the Moors, long established suppliers of slaves, and soon discovered when they edged towards the Senegal River, other African peoples engaged in this slave trade with the Moors of North Africa. 
 
**What role does the Portuguese come to play in the trade of African slaves**?

By the beginning of the 1500’s Portuguese had turned themselves into both a major purchaser and seller of slaves in West Africa. 

 They had essentially become middle-men in a trade in slaves in West Africa that had existed prior to their arrival by entering into this trade they  transformed not only the slave trade, but the practice of slavery itself greatly expanding it across the world.

text:
**1**. What were the variety of exchanges that occurred in Native American Socities? What role did giving play in establishing status and obligation? 
*The variety of exchanges that occurred in the Native American Societies, were resources, labor, ideas, techniques and religious practices. Most people who acquired this wealth gave it away, thus earning prestige and they were thought of highly by individual groups. They also gained respect.*

**2**. What developments occur in Europe that help set the foundation for European exploration and empire building? 
*The developments that occurred in Europe that helped set the foundation for European exploration and empire building, was the growth in population that recovered from the plague from the 14th century, population growth brought the growth of national economies and rising demand for consumer goods, and the growing demand lead to ship building so that the merchants could compete for goods and profit whilst expanding trade, the trade also lead to the rise of large kingdoms and powerful monarchs, only big empires could pull together large scales of trades, and finally, the trades were commonly involved with Asia, which lead to transportation as well.*

**3**. What were Portugal's interest in slaves? What role do the Portuguese come into play in the trade of African slaves? *Portugal's interest in slaves was because there was an increasing need for slave labor. By the 1500s, the Portuguese became the largest major purchaser and seller of slaves in West Africa.*

text:
Internal tension in the Native American empires of the Americas aided Spanish attempts to create their empire because the spanish managed labor relations through a legal system known as the encomeienda, an exploitive feudal arrangement in which Spain tied Indian laborers to vast estates.  The Spanish crown granted a person not only land but a specified number of natives as well.  They brutalized their laborers with punishing labor.  

The racial system established by the Spanish in the New World was in the mid-1600's, rooted in medieval practices, called the Sistema de Castas organized individuals were organized into various racial groups based upon their supposed "purity of blood".  Various classifications-often elaborately arrived at-became almost prerequisites for social and political advancement in Spanish colonial society.  Peninsulares-Iberian-born Spaniards, or Esponoles-occupied the highest levels of administration and acquired the greatest estates.  Their descendants, New World-born Spaniards, or criollos, occupied the next rung and rivaled the peninsulares for wealth and opportunity.  Mestizos-a term used to describe those of mixed Spanish/Indian heritage-followed.

title: 1. The New World | The American Yawp

text: The differences between the Europeans and the Natives of North America were great. The Europeans had established cities with bustling commerce, established trade routes both on land and sea. They had established governments, monarchies, that defined social status. The religion was also a powerful establishment that pretty much pervaded all of society. Whereas the Native Americans, while they did have cities and established civilizations, most often their communities were small by comparison. Often they were nomadic tribes and had different outlooks on religion, trade, possessions, relationships, and the very fact that they were indeed closer to the earth gave them a different outlook on life in general. For one thing, they were not as power hungry oriented nor was the accumulation of vast possesions their goals in life. They used the land and had their "turfs" so to speak, but they were not into the empirical conquest thing". They believed in the Great Spirit in the sky, the same God of the Europeans, but some tribes had given over to the darker side of demonic worship and sacrifice. For the European who first landed in North America it must have been quite the culture shock, enough so that they came to call the Native Americans...savages.

text:
First 

What developments occur in Europe that set the foundation for exploration and empire building?

Population growth within Europe and their demands or needs caused in increase in shipping and trading as merchants moved to take advantage of these opportunities. Increased trade created greater monarchies that sought to increase their power, influence, and wealth. These "empires" were then capable of supporting the cost of exploration and trade across the oceans. Also, dramatic social and political change as well as the depletion of resources within North America lead to violent competition and clashes among the Native tribes causing great division and chaos, a fertile ground for their conquest by the Europeans. It is then that the Europeans arrive.
